summary: This document is an email chain between Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys and Assistant U.S. Attorneys regarding discovery issues in Maxwell's criminal case. The emails discuss technical problems with evidence production, including missing attachments, metadata issues with files from Jeffrey Epstein's devices, and logistical challenges delivering discovery to Maxwell in prison.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell; she sends detailed requests about discovery production issues, specifically regarding metadata and file formats.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell; corresponds with prosecutors about discovery issues, including sending a hard drive to Maxwell in prison and requesting metadata for files from Epstein's devices.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell; copied on discovery-related emails between defense and prosecution teams.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell; copied on discovery-related emails regarding technical production issues.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case; her attorneys are trying to get discovery materials to her at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC).

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in Ghislaine Maxwell's case; mentioned as someone who may need to issue an order if the MDC refuses to accept a discovery drive.

connections.description: Menninger is a defense attorney representing Maxwell in her criminal case, as evidenced by her detailed work on discovery issues.
Everdell is a defense attorney corresponding with prosecutors about getting discovery materials to Maxwell in prison.
Pagliuca is a defense attorney copied on discovery emails concerning Maxwell's case.
Sternheim is a defense attorney copied on discovery emails concerning Maxwell's case.
Both are defense attorneys working together on Maxwell's case, coordinating on discovery issues.
The discovery materials being discussed include files recovered from Epstein's devices, linking Maxwell to Epstein's case.

events.title: Searches of Epstein residences
events.description: The FBI conducted searches of Jeffrey Epstein's residences, seizing CDs containing images that later became part of the discovery in Ghislaine Maxwell's case.

events.title: SUPP discovery production
events.description: The prosecution produced supplemental discovery materials to Maxwell's defense team, which included files from Epstein's devices and images from seized CDs.

events.title: Discovery issues raised
events.description: Defense attorney Christian Everdell sends a detailed list of discovery issues to prosecutors, including problems with metadata, missing attachments, and logistical challenges delivering materials to Maxwell in prison.

keyFacts: Defense attorneys are having difficulty getting discovery materials to Ghislaine Maxwell in prison due to MDC restrictions on external drives.

Over 109,000 emails were produced without attachments, and over 110,000 electronic documents from Epstein's devices have metadata showing 'date created' or 'date last modified' dates in July 2020 or later, raising questions about evidence handling.
Images seized from Epstein's residences in 2019 were produced without CART numbers, making it difficult to trace their origin to specific devices.
Prosecutors acknowledge that for carved or deleted files from Epstein's devices, no metadata was recovered, limiting what information is available about those files.
The email chain reveals ongoing technical disputes between prosecution and defense about the format and completeness of discovery production in Maxwell's case.
